33.title: The Building Blocks
33.subtitle: Lesson 1
33.content:
NEW YORK, NY – At the House of Juilliard in the heart of historic Lincoln Center resides one of the world’s largest inventories of Steinway & Sons pianos: Steinways on concert stages, in practice rooms, faculty studios, classrooms and dance studios.

Chief Piano Technician Mario Igrec said the school owns approximately 260 pianos – 248 are Steinways and 231 of those are Steinway grands. That grand collection includes 10 Model D’s, 63 Model B’s, 5 Model A’s, 98 Model L’s, 42 Model O’s, 12 Model M’s and one Model S.

The New York piano maker’s relationship goes back to 1924 and the founding of the Juilliard Graduate School. According to The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Music, the school fulfilled last wishes of Augustus D. Juilliard, a wealthy textile merchant who left about $20 million for deserving music students to further their education. Two years later, the Graduate School merged with the Institute of Musical Art to become the Juilliard School of Music. The Institute opened its doors in 1905 under Frank Damrosch, godson of Franz Liszt and head of music education for New York City.

1001.title: Hidden Musical Patterns: Myth or Fact?
1001.subtitle: Lesson 1
1001.description: Do Hidden Musical Patterns actually exist? Truth or myth? On this video we'll reveal if hidden musical patterns indeed exist or not and give you a glimpse into the  secrets that all great pianists know but teachers never tell you.

1002.title: How to Play 50 Songs with Just Four Chords
1002.subtitle: Lesson 2
1002.description: Is it possible to learn how to play 50 of the greatest #1 hits by using just one hidden musical pattern? In this video you will learn how this works, step-by-step.

1003.title: Adding a Fancy Bass Line
1003.subtitle: Lesson 3
1003.description: How to make your playing instantly sound more sophisticated by using an easy trick. Discover the power of the bass line and how to add it to any song you want to play.

1004.title: Playing a Medley of the Greatest Hits
1004.subtitle: Lesson 4
1004.description:
Learning what you see on this video will guarantee that you impress anyone you want with your piano playing. If you are able to achieve what we show in this video... they won't believe it is possible! (...and the secret is that learning it just takes a few minutes!)

Expect to receive the Companion Book shortly.

1005.title: Companion Book: The Fifty #1 Hits Songbook
1005.subtitle: Lesson 5
1005.description:
This 27-page book will add 50 songs to your repertoire. Learn how to play through the 50 most popular piano songs by using just 4 chords.

This is the companion eBook to the video series "The Hidden Patterns of Music"

1006.title: The Power of Musical Formulas
1006.subtitle: Master Class
1006.description:
What if you could instantly discover how music formulas work?

Were the greatest musicians of all time aware that these music formulas existed?(...from Beethoven and Mozart to Ray Charles and Elton John?)

How did these musicians use them to be able to play the piano by ear, improvise, and compose their own music?

...and most importantly, how can YOU put music formulas to work for you, so you can become the piano player that you always wanted to be?

1007.title: Part I: Musical Formulas in Action
1007.subtitle: Chords in Both Hands
1007.description:
Learn how to play 'Let it Be' by The Beatles, using Music Formulas, in an 'easy' version.

You will learn how to play just three music formulas, and with them, you will be able to play the entire song. This lesson is not just about playing and impressing your friends and family, but also about understanding how powerful Musical Formulas can be. Once you discover the logic behind the music, the possibilities become infinite...!

1008.title: Time to Play
1008.subtitle: Let it Be - Play Along (Easy)
1008.description:
This is an 'easy' level, play-along video, which contains the chords and lyrics to 'Let it Be' by The Beatles so that you play and sing along - and put the theory into practice.

Once you have mastered this version, go to the next lesson to add an incredible bass line.

1009.title: Part II: Musical Formulas in Action
1009.subtitle: Adding a Bass Line
1009.description:
It's time to add a bass line! Learning songs can't get easier, when you learn using music formulas.

Playing just chords is good to start, but what will really get your playing going, is actually playing different things in both hands. Since the entire song of 'Let it Be' contains just three music formulas, you only have to learn three bass lines. The bass lines are easy to learn and will make your music stand out and impress your audience!

1010.title: It's Show Time!
1010.subtitle: Let it Be - Play Along (Intermediate)
1010.description:
This is the 'intermediate' level, play-along video, which contains the chords, bass line, and lyrics to 'Let it Be' by The Beatles so that you play and sing along.

It's to shine! By using music formulas you will be able to learn this entire song in just a few minutes and impress your friends and family. This is how powerful music formulas can be. Imagine if you were to learn more about the hidden patterns of music.

1011.title: The Final Secret is Revealed
1011.subtitle: Master Class
1011.description:
On the last episodes of our premium series "The Hidden Patterns of Music", we started uncovering what all great musicians know but teachers never tell you.

However, you might still have many unanswered burning questions:
- How is it possible that we were able to play 50 of the greatest songs of all time with just 4 chords?
- Were they originally like that?
- Or did we do anything to make them playable with just 4 chords?

On this video, we'll be revealing the secret. And the answer to this mystery, will also reveal a technique that will let you learn new songs up to "10 times faster".

Discover The Logic Behind Music Now:

3205.title: The Harmony Guides

Whatever sound you want to create - romantic, suspenseful, cheerful or anything else- you can learn how in just 4 simple steps.

Be able to practice anywhere. Play chords. Play melodies. Or play both at the same time, using The Piano Encyclopedia's groundbreaking technology. On a laptop or desktop computer, you may use the mouse to play melodies, and the computer's keyboard, to play chords. The Virtual Piano will play like a real piano, without needing one. 3208.title: The 1000 Exclusive Video Gallery

Discover The Logic Behind Music Now:

3209.title: The Elite Membership

Participate in exclusive piano competitions, gain recognition, and get access to members only premium content.

Discover The Logic Behind Music Now:

5004.title: Holiday Songs Book
5004.subtitle: Book
5004.description:
It is The Piano Encyclopedia's brand new Holiday Songs - for Piano Book. This book includes the most popular Holiday songs that you will be able to play to bring joy to your family! With 30 pages of content and 40 original illustrations, this book gives you everything that you need to play and sing these holiday classics. We have included the lyrics, chords, and special piano charts to make it very simple.

This is our tangible way of thanking you for being a part of The Piano Encyclopedia family!

5005.title: All Time Classics for Piano
5005.subtitle: Book
5005.description: It's our 'All Time Classics - Songs for Piano', 26-page piano songbook. This book contains songs that you will be able to play by yourself following the lyrics, chords and special piano charts that we have included for you.

5500.title: An Inspirational Story: The Trailer
5500.subtitle: Learning to play the piano at 59 years old
5500.description:
When Lynn Bratchett called us to get help on upgrading to the latest version of our Digital Home-Study Course 'The Logic Behind Music' he said to us 'The Piano Encyclopedia has changed my life'. Lynn started learning piano for the first time at age 59, and is now giving paid public concerts, recitals, and auditions. Learn about his inspiring story and get tips on how you too can reach your own musical dreams.

After completing this video, you may watch the complete interview on the upcoming video.

5501.title: An Inspirational Story: The Complete Interview
5501.subtitle: From zero knowledge to giving piano concerts
5501.description: This is the complete interview of Lynn Bratchett where he will tell you in his own words his highly inspirational story: how he was able to go from not knowing the name of the keys of the piano to giving paid concerts, recitals, and auditions! Learn about his motivating story and how you too can reach your own musical dreams.

6101.title: What Smart Piano Players Do
6101.subtitle: Master Class
6101.description: This is the first episode of 'What All Great Musicians Know But Teachers Never Tell You'. Video-lesson episodes designed to radically change the way you approach learning piano, and how you think about music; by showing you how you can use the hidden patterns of music to your advantage. Skills like improvisation, playing by ear, and composition will feel just a step away after you complete this lesson series. On this episode, you will discover what allows smart piano players to play any song they hear, without sheet music, instantly; and why smart piano players never play the same song the same way twice.

6201.title: The Shortcuts of Great Pianists
6201.subtitle: Master Class
6201.description: This is the second episode of 'What All Great Musicians Know But Teachers Never Tell You'. On this episode, you will learn how great piano players can go through a worldwide musical journey while staying in front of their piano. Discover how to play music from distant cultures while using only three specific groups of keys. And most importantly, completely change your approach to mastering the piano and reaching your life-long dreams.

6301.title: The Making of a Smart Piano Player
6301.subtitle: Master Class
6301.description: This is the third episode of 'What All Great Musicians Know But Teachers Never Tell You'. On this episode, you will learn how the most talented musicians in the world can change the entire emotion of any tune by changing just one note... and how you can do it too! We will not only reveal how this technique works step-by-step; but moreover, we will uncover the hidden patterns of music and show you how music works in a practical way.

7101.title: Introduction
7101.subtitle: Master Class
7101.description: What are the mistakes that aspiring piano players make and you should avoid? Watch this lesson to get the right mindset on how to learn how to play the piano and develop a skill that will last for a lifetime!

7102.title: The Answers

7102.description: The 8 mistakes and their answers are revealed. What are the mistakes that aspiring piano players make and you should avoid? Watch this lesson to get the right mindset on how to learn how to play the piano and develop a skill that will last for a lifetime!

8101.title: The Sustain Pedal
8101.subtitle: How to use the pedal for legato and colouring (Part 1/2)
8101.content:
ABOUT JÓZEF HOFMANN

Józef Hofmann is considered "one of the best pianists of all times". He was the only private student of the world-acclaimed pianist and composer Anton Rubinstein, who was the composition teacher of the legendary composer Tchaikovsky. The Piano Encyclopedia’s highly-trained staff of expert musicians has made a tremendous and elaborated investigation, digging up lost historical sources and combining them with modern expert knowledge, to provide you with the ultimate answers to every piano question.

About the most used pedal

The difference between the sustain and damper pedal? How do they work?

“The damper pedal, sustain pedal, or sustaining pedal are many names for the same pedal. They are synonyms. It is the pedal to the right of the other two, and it is the one that is used more often.

How does it work? It raises all the dampers off the strings so that they keep vibrating after the player releases the key.

The damper pedal lets the pianist sustain notes which would otherwise be out of reach, for instance, in accompanying chords and accomplish legato passages (smoothly connected notes), which would have no possible fingering otherwise.

However, the damper pedal is not just used for legato purposes; it is also used for "colouring." Depressing the sustain pedal causes all the strings to vibrate sympathetically with whichever notes are being played, which greatly enriches the piano's tone, creating an overall change in the "colour" of the piano sound.”

Legato passages and the pedal

Could you explain to me what does playing "legato" mean. and if it is related to the usage of the sustain pedal?

“Let me explain. The word legato literally means “connected” or “bound together.” Playing legato means transitioning from note to note with no intervening silence. Or almost no silence - as smoothly as possible.

The pedal is of great use when joining two otherwise unconnected notes or chords together, that cannot be connected in any other way.”

The use of the pedal for colouring

What is the real use of the sustain pedal?

“Primarily it serves to prolong such tones as we cannot hold with the fingers. But it is also one of the greatest means for colouring.

The employment of it should always be governed by the ear.”

How to use the sustain pedal

When is it too much pedaling? When is it too little?

“To answer the question, you must remember that the sustain pedal has two principal purposes:

1. Allowing the sound to continue even after we release the keys
2. Changing the timbre of the sound, making it deeper, warmer, more intense, more ‘alive’.

Avoid the use of the pedal completely and it will be difficult to bring enough emotion to your music. Arthur Rubinstein once said: “The more I play, the more I am convinced the pedal is the soul of the pianoforte!”.

Do not make this mistake of leaving the pedal on while the harmony changes. This will create a muddy sound. “Abusing the pedal is only a means of covering up a lack of technique” - Claude Debussy

When to use it? You'll want to change the pedal when harmonies change. As soon as the harmonies change, release the pedal; and then push it back down. This will produce a clean sound instead of a muddy one.

In order to understand if the harmonies change or not, on any particular piece, you need to have an understanding of how music works. How chords and scales are related; and how they affect the harmony of a piece. Also, if your desire is to learn how to improvise, compose, and play by ear - then studying the logic behind music is a must.”

8102.title: The Sustain Pedal
8102.subtitle: What is half pedaling and when to use it? (Part 2/2)
8102.content:
ABOUT JÓZEF HOFMANN

Józef Hofmann is considered "one of the best pianists of all times". He was the only private student of the world-acclaimed pianist and composer Anton Rubinstein, who was the composition teacher of the legendary composer Tchaikovsky. The Piano Encyclopedia’s highly-trained staff of expert musicians has made a tremendous and elaborated investigation, digging up lost historical sources and combining them with modern expert knowledge, to provide you with the ultimate answers to every piano question.

Half-Pedaling

What is half-pedaling and how to do it correctly?

"The sustain pedal does not have to be completely on or off. You can push the pedal down, slightly. This is called half-pedalling (not pushing the pedal all the way down).

When you partially press down the sustain pedal the dampers touch the strings very slightly. This allows a subtle variation of the sound quality that creates a rich tone. It is usually considered an advanced technique that can enhance the sound of particular notes you are playing by using different amounts of pedal. I suggest you to experiment with it to enrich your playing and enhance musical expression.”

An example of a musical piece that is played with half-pedaling by some pianists is Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata. Most recent digital pianos also support this effect.

How to use the pedal

Please tell me how to use the pedal. I find that in some pieces there is no mark under the measures to show me when it should be used. Is there any rule which you can give me?

“Assuming that you have in mind the artistic use of the pedal, I regret to say that there is no more a rule for this than for the mixing of colours upon the palette of a painter who strives for some particular shade or tint. He knows that blue and yellow make green, that red and blue make purple; but those are ground colours which he can rarely use.

For the finer shades he has to experiment, to consult his eye and his judgment. The relation between the pedal and the player's ear is exactly similar to that of the palette and the painter's eye. Generally speaking (from sad experience) it is far more important to know when not to use the pedal than when to use it. We must refrain from its use whenever there is the slightest danger of unintentional mingling of tones. This is best avoided by taking the pedal after striking the tone upon which it is to act, and to release it promptly and simultaneously with the striking of the next tone. It may be at once taken again, and this alternation must be kept up where there is either a change of harmony or a succession of "passing notes."

This is the only positive rule I can give, but even this is often violated. Let your ear be the guardian of your right foot. Accustom your ear to harmonic and melodic clarity, and—listen closely. To teach the use of the pedal independent of the action of your own ear is impossible.”

A general rule about the pedal

Should I use the pedal with each melody note? Should like a general rule.

“The treading upon the pedal should always follow immediately after the striking of the note for which it is intended, or else there will be discords arising from the mingling of that note with the one preceding it. This is the general rule. Exceptions there are, of course, but they occur only in certain moments when a mingling of tones is purposed for some special effect.”

Let your ear guide your pedalling

In Weber's "Storm" should the pedal be held down throughout the entire piece, as directed? It produces quite a discord.

“Without knowing this piece, even by name, I may say that the pianos of Weber's time had a tone of such short duration and volume that the discords resulting from a continuous use of the pedal were not so noticeable, as they are now upon the modern piano with its magnificent volume and duration of tone. Hence, the pedal must now be used with the utmost caution.

Generally speaking, I say—again—that the ear is the "sole" guide of the foot upon the pedal.”

Use pedal with caution in playing Bach

Is Bach's music ever played with the pedal?

“There is no piano-music that forbids in playing the use of the pedal. Even where the texture of a piece does not require the pedal—which happens very rarely—the player might employ it as an aid where the reach of his hand proves insufficient to hold all the parts of a harmony together. With Bach the pedal is often very important; for, by judicious use—as, for instance, in the cases of organ-point—it accumulates harmonic tones, holds the fundamental tone and thus produces effects not dissimilar to the organ.

Qualitatively speaking, the pedal is as necessary in Bach's music as in any other; quantitatively, I recommend the utmost caution in its use, so as not to blur the fine texture of his polyphony.”

8103.title: The Soft Pedal
8103.subtitle: When to use the soft pedal as an expressive device? (Part 1/2)
8103.content:
ABOUT JÓZEF HOFMANN

Józef Hofmann is considered "one of the best pianists of all times". He was the only private student of the world-acclaimed pianist and composer Anton Rubinstein, who was the composition teacher of the legendary composer Tchaikovsky. The Piano Encyclopedia’s highly-trained staff of expert musicians has made a tremendous and elaborated investigation, digging up lost historical sources and combining them with modern expert knowledge, to provide you with the ultimate answers to every piano question.

About the soft pedal

Why is it called the "una-corda" pedal?

“On an acoustic piano, grand or upright, the soft pedal is the leftmost pedal of the three.

Why is it also called the "una-corda" pedal? "Una-corda" translates to "one-string" in Italian. On older pianos, there used to be just two strings for each of the notes. When pressing the "una-corda" pedal, the whole piano mechanism, including the keyboard, slightly shifted to the right. This would move the hammers over so they would only strike one of the strings instead of the two, producing a softer sound.

Newer pianos have three strings for each note for most notes of the keyboard, but the mechanism is the same. The result is not just a decrease in volume (dynamics), but also, it modifies and softens its tone quality.”

Soft pedal: grand vs upright piano

Does the soft pedal produce the same effect on a grand piano and an upright piano? I played on a grand piano and the soft pedal seems to have a different effect than the one on my upright piano.

“The short answer is: no. On a grand piano, the soft pedal reduces volume (dynamics) and also changes the tone quality by producing a mellower sound. On the contrary, on an upright piano, the soft pedal merely reduces the volume.

True "una-corda" or soft-pedals only exist on grand pianos. On upright pianos, the soft pedal operates a mechanism that moves the hammers' resting position closer to the strings. Since the hammers have less distance to travel, this reduces the speed at which they hit the strings, and hence the volume is reduced, but this does not change tone quality in the way the "una-corda" pedal does on a grand piano.”

When to use the soft pedal? An expressive device

Could you please explain me when should I use the soft pedal? Is it just about dynamics?

“The soft pedal is not just about dynamics. It is about a change in color in the piano sound.

The soft pedal is said to produce a soft and ethereal tone. You should use it to add variety to your playing and use it on particular music sections. For example, when you play the repetition of a theme, you may play it using the soft pedal to create a new and different sound. It's a wonderful way to highlight certain sections of your music.

When appropriately used, the soft pedal is an extraordinarily expressive device that can add new color and depth to your music.”

Do not over-use the soft pedal

Should the "Gavotte in A" of Gluck-Brahms be played without the soft pedal? Does a liberal use of the soft pedal tend to make the student lazy in using a light touch?

“Your first question is too general, as there is no piece of music that should be played entirely with or without the soft pedal; it is used only when a certain change of colouring is proposed. A too frequent use of the soft pedal does tend to a neglect of the pianissimo touch, and it should, therefore, be discouraged.”

8104.title: The Soft Pedal
8104.subtitle: When should I use it? Color or dynamics? (Part 2/2)
8104.content:
ABOUT JÓZEF HOFMANN

Józef Hofmann is considered "one of the best pianists of all times". He was the only private student of the world-acclaimed pianist and composer Anton Rubinstein, who was the composition teacher of the legendary composer Tchaikovsky. The Piano Encyclopedia’s highly-trained staff of expert musicians has made a tremendous and elaborated investigation, digging up lost historical sources and combining them with modern expert knowledge, to provide you with the ultimate answers to every piano question.

To produce a softer tone

Should the expression "p" be executed by the aid of the soft pedal or through the fingers?

“The soft pedal serves to change the quality of tone, not the quantity. It should therefore never be used to hide a faulty piano (or soft) touch. Mere softness of tone should always be produced by a decrease of finger-force and a lessening of the raising of the fingers. The soft pedal should be employed only when the softness of tone is coupled with a change of colouring, such as lies within its range of action.”

Soft pedal. When to use it?

When should I use the soft pedal?

“The soft pedal is not just about dynamics. It is about a change in color in the piano sound.

The soft pedal is said to produce a soft and ethereal tone. You should use it to add variety to your playing and use it on particular music sections. For example, when you play the repetition of a theme, you may play it using the soft pedal to create a new and different sound. It's a wonderful way to highlight certain sections of your music.

When appropriately used, the soft pedal is an extraordinarily expressive device that can add new color and depth to your music.”

Afraid to play without the "soft" pedal

My piano has a rather loud tone to which my people object, and urge me to play with the soft pedal. I use it most of the time, but am afraid now to play without it. What would you advise?

“If a soft touch and sound are liked, have the mechanism of your piano changed at the factory. I found myself in the bad condition at one time that I could not play certain passages independently of the position of my foot on the soft pedal. Such is the strength of association that very soon a constant use of the soft pedal produces physical inability to play unless the foot is pressing the pedal.”

Using the two pedals at once

May the damper pedal and the soft pedal be used simultaneously, or would this be detrimental to the piano?

“Since the mechanisms of the two pedals are entirely separate and independent of each other you may use them simultaneously, provided that the character of a particular place in your piece justifies it.”

8105.title: The Best Practice Routine (Part 1/3)
8105.subtitle: Should I practice with the two hands separately
8105.content:
ABOUT JÓZEF HOFMANN

Józef Hofmann is considered "one of the best pianists of all times". He was the only private student of the world-acclaimed pianist and composer Anton Rubinstein, who was the composition teacher of the legendary composer Tchaikovsky. The Piano Encyclopedia’s highly-trained staff of expert musicians has made a tremendous and elaborated investigation, digging up lost historical sources and combining them with modern expert knowledge, to provide you with the ultimate answers to every piano question.

When reading over a new piece

When studying a new composition for the first time, which is preferable: to practise first with separate hands or together?

“When first looking over a new composition both hands should be employed, if possible, for this is necessary to obtain, approximately, at least, a mental picture of it. If the player's technique is too insufficient for this the deciphering must, of course, be done for each hand separately.”

Mastering a piece: practising the two parts separately

In order to master the performance of a composition, should the hands practise their parts separately?

“If this is not the first time you are reading the piece, and provided you have formed a general idea of the piece, it is well to practise the hands separately, because you can, in this way, concentrate your attention upon the work of each hand. As soon, however, as each hand knows its work the hands should play together in order now to pursue the musical purpose for which the separate practice was only a technical preparation.”

Time to devote to technical exercises

Should I practise studies in general for my progress or should I confine myself strictly to my technical exercises?

“Your strictly technical exercises should occupy one-quarter of the entire time you can give to your work. Two quarters you should use for the technical preparation of the difficult passages you encounter in the pieces you are studying, and during the last quarter these passages which have been thus prepared should be ranged into their proper places in the pieces, in order that you may not lose your view of the totality of the pieces while studying or practising details.

Apart from pure practice, it is vital that you develop a solid understanding of how music works from the very beginning. Technique will take you nowhere if you are not able to understand how chords, scales, and intervals relate to each other. Your understanding of music should be enough so that you are able to identify the underlying patterns behind the pieces you are playing.”

Do not rise the piano's stool too high

Are the best results at the piano attained by sitting high or low?

“As a general rule, I do not recommend a high seat at the piano, because this induces the employment of the arm and shoulders rather than of the fingers, and is, of course, very harmful to the technique. As to the exact height of the seat, you will have to experiment for yourself and find out at which height you can play longest with the least fatigue.”

The only kind of practice worth while

In purely technical, i.e., mechanical, practice may I have a book or a magazine on the music-stand and read?

“This question will appear grotesque to anyone who has not thought of it, yet it is legitimate; for I know positively that this crime upon themselves has been committed by many. I cannot warn students too strongly against this pernicious habit. It is far better to practise only half as long, but with concentrated attention. Even purely mechanical matter must be transmitted to the motor-centres of the brain through the agencies of the ear and eye in order to bring beneficial technical results.

If the brain is otherwise occupied it becomes insensible to the impression of the work in hand, and practise thus done is a complete waste of time. Not only should we not read, but also not think of anything else but the work before us, if we expect results. Concentration is the first letter in the alphabet of success.

Also, you must remember: all of the greatest pianists of history were also composers. It is crucial that you understand the logic behind music to be able to master the piano. This will be your only path to not just becoming great at this instrument, but also, to develop the skills of improvisation, composition, and playing by ear.”

8106.title: The Best Practice Routine (Part 2/3)
8106.subtitle: Four Ways to Study a Piano Piece
8106.content:
ABOUT JÓZEF HOFMANN

Józef Hofmann is considered "one of the best pianists of all times". He was the only private student of the world-acclaimed pianist and composer Anton Rubinstein, who was the composition teacher of the legendary composer Tchaikovsky. The Piano Encyclopedia’s highly-trained staff of expert musicians has made a tremendous and elaborated investigation, digging up lost historical sources and combining them with modern expert knowledge, to provide you with the ultimate answers to every piano question.

Playing with cold hands

Shall I, when my hands are cold and stiff, play at once difficult and fatiguing things in order to limber them up?

“In forcing things with cold hands you always run the danger of overstraining, while with a gradual limbering you may safely try the same tasks with impunity. Handle the piano lightly while the hands are cold, and increase both force and speed only when the hands have gained their normal temperature and elasticity. This may take half or even three-quarters of an hour. It may be accelerated by putting the hands in hot water before playing, but this should not be done too often, because it is apt to weaken the nerves of the hands.”

Is the study of scales important for a beginner?

Must all study of the piano absolutely begin with the study of scales?

“If you are a beginner, this is my recommendation. Scale exercises should not be attempted until a good finger-touch has been formed and the very important action of the thumb in the scale has been fully prepared. After that, however, I consider the practising of scales important, not only for the fingers, but also for the discipline of the ear with regard to the feeling of tonality (key), understanding of intervals, and the comprehension of the total compass of the piano.”

Scales are not just about technique; understanding the relationship between scales and chords is what will let you improvise, compose, and play by ear. You will be able to learn more about these concepts in The Piano Encyclopedia's Digital Home-Study Course "The Logic Behind Music".

The morning practice on the piano for a concert pianist

In resuming my studies in the morning what should I play first?

“If you are looking forward to become a concert pianist this is what I recommend. Begin with your technical work. Scales in all tonalities, each at least twice well rendered. First slowly, one after another, then somewhat quicker, but never very quickly as long as you are not absolutely sure that both hands are perfectly even, and that neither false notes nor wrong fingerings occur.

To play the scales wrong is just as much a matter of habit as to play them right—only easier. You can get very firmly settled in the habit of striking a certain note wrong every time it occurs unless you take the trouble of counteracting the formation of such a habit.

After these scales play them in octaves from the wrist, slowly and without tiring it by lifting the hand to a needless height. After this play either Czerny or Cramer, then Bach, and finally Mozart, Beethoven, Chopin, and so on. If you have the time to do it, play one hour in the morning on technical studies and use one hour for the difficult places in the works you are studying. In the afternoon play another hour, and this hour you devote to interpretation.

I mean by this that you should now apply æsthetically what you have technically gained in the morning by uniting your mechanical advantages with the ideal conception which you have formed in your mind of the work you are studying.”

Four ways to study a piano piece

Should a composition be studied away from the piano?

“There are four ways to study a composition:

1. On the piano with the music.
2. Away from the piano with the music.
3. On the piano without the music.
4. Away from the piano without the music

Two (2) and four (4) are mentally the most taxing and fatiguing ways, no doubt; but they also serve best to develop the memory and what we mean by "scope," which is a faculty of great importance.”

The Piano Encyclopedia has been featured on Forbes as the company that is "revolutionizing the way people learn to play the piano". With students in over 75 countries, thousands of testimonials, and over 250,000 raving fans on Facebook, you can guarantee yourself that you will be using a tested and proven curriculum that will help you achieve your goals. Learn how to improvise, compose, and play by ear, using The Piano Encyclopedia's Digital Home-Study Course "The Logic Behind Music."

Practising many hours a day

Will I advance quicker by practising many more hours a day?

“Playing too much in one day has often a deteriorating effect upon one's studies, because work is profitable, after all, only if done with full mental concentration, which can be sustained only for a certain length of time. Some exhaust their power of concentration quicker than others; but, however long it may have lasted, once it is exhausted all further work is like unrolling a scroll which we have laboriously rolled up. Practise self-examination, and if you notice that your interest is waning—stop. Remember that in studying the matter of quantity is of moment only when coupled with quality. Attention, concentration, devotion, will make unnecessary any inquiries as to how much you ought to practise.”

8107.title: The Best Practice Routine (Part 3/3)
8107.subtitle: The value and correct practice of phrasing
8107.content:
ABOUT JÓZEF HOFMANN

Józef Hofmann is considered "one of the best pianists of all times". He was the only private student of the world-acclaimed pianist and composer Anton Rubinstein, who was the composition teacher of the legendary composer Tchaikovsky. The Piano Encyclopedia’s highly-trained staff of expert musicians has made a tremendous and elaborated investigation, digging up lost historical sources and combining them with modern expert knowledge, to provide you with the ultimate answers to every piano question.

The best way to work up a quick tempo

Is it ever a waste of time to practise a piece over and over again for months as slowly as a beginner and with utmost concentration? After having done so and gradually working up a tempo, I then find I cannot play so fast as I want to. Is it not wise to begin all over again as slowly as possible? I prefer to work this way, but have been told that one gets "stale," studying the same music for a long time. Do you advise practising with or without the pedal?

“Slow practice is undoubtedly the basis for quick playing; but quick playing is not an immediate result of slow practice. Quick playing must be tried from time to time, with increasing frequency and heightened speed, even at a temporary loss of clearness.

This loss is easily regained by subsequent returns to slow practice. After all, we must first learn to think quickly through the course of a piece before we can play it quickly, and this mental endeavour, too, will be greatly aided by occasional trials in a quicker tempo. As for getting "stale," a variety of pieces is necessary to preserve the freshness of each one.

Regarding the pedal, I suggest that you use it judiciously from the very beginning of the study of a new piece; though never in finger exercises.”

The student who cannot play fast music

I find great difficulty in playing anything that goes quick, though in a more moderate tempo I can play my pieces faultlessly. Every teacher I had promised to develop my speed, but they all failed. Can you give me a hint how to overcome my difficulty?

“Quickness of action, of motion, even of resolution, cannot be acquired by training alone; it must partly be inborn. I assume that your piano-playing is one phase of a general slowness. There is but one remedy for that. You have relied upon your teachers to develop your speed—you should have relied upon your own will-power. Try to will it and to will it often; you will see the ability keep step with the exertions of your will.”

Quick tempo: watch your breathing

What is the purpose of associating breathing with piano playing, and to what extent should it be practised?

“Breathing is as important in piano playing as in all physical exertion, and more so when we speak of pieces that entail the use of great muscular force; for this causes a quickening in the action of the heart; respiration naturally keeps step with it, and the result is often a forcible breathing through the mouth.

Players resort to open-mouth breathing in such cases because they cannot help themselves. If, at the last spurt of a bicycle race, we should call to the wheelmen, "Breathe through the nose!" we could not wonder if our advice remains unheeded. This open-mouth breathing, however, need not be learned; it is the self-help of nature.

I recommend breathing through the nose as long as possible. It is more wholesome than mouth-breathing, and it refreshes the head more. When physical exertion becomes too great then you will neither need nor heed my advice or anybody's; your nature will find its own line of least resistance.”

Counting out loud

Is counting aloud injurious to a pupil's playing—that is, does not the sound of the voice confuse the pupil in getting the correct tone of the note struck?

“Loud counting can hardly ever be injurious—especially not while the pupil is dealing with time and rhythm. This part mastered or fully understood, the audible counting may be lessened and finally abandoned. During practice loud counting is of inestimable value, for it develops and strengthens rhythmic feeling better than anything else will, and, besides, it is an infallible guide to find the points of stress in a phrase.”

The value and correct practice of phrasing

Can you give an amateur a concise definition of phrasing and a few helpful suggestions as to clear phrasing?

“Phrasing is a rational division and subdivision of musical sentences, and serves to make them intelligible. It corresponds closely with punctuation in literature and its recitation. Find out the start, the end, and the culminating point of your phrase. The last-named is usually to be found upon the highest note of the phrase, while the former are usually indicated by phrasing slurs.

Generally speaking, the rising of the melody is combined with an increase of strength up to the point of culmination, where, in keeping with the note design, the decrease of strength sets in. For artistic phrasing it is of the utmost importance properly to recognize the principal mood of the piece, for this must, naturally, influence the rendition of every detail in it. A phrase occurring in an agitated movement, for instance, will have to be rendered very differently from a similar-looking phrase in a slow, dreamy movement.”

8108.title: Sight Reading
8108.subtitle: The best way to improve sight-reading
8108.content:
ABOUT JÓZEF HOFMANN

Józef Hofmann is considered "one of the best pianists of all times". He was the only private student of the world-acclaimed pianist and composer Anton Rubinstein, who was the composition teacher of the legendary composer Tchaikovsky. The Piano Encyclopedia’s highly-trained staff of expert musicians has made a tremendous and elaborated investigation, digging up lost historical sources and combining them with modern expert knowledge, to provide you with the ultimate answers to every piano question.

A prima vista

What is sight-reading?

“Sight-reading, also called a prima vista (Italian meaning "at first sight", is the reading and performing of a piece of music that the performer has not seen before. Basically, sight-reading is reading a piece you haven't seen before and playing it on the spot without any preparation.”

Studio musicians often record pieces on the first take without having seen them before. The expense of the studio, musicians, and techs makes sight-reading skills essential. Typically, a studio performance is "rehearsed" only once to check for copying errors before recording the final track. Many professional big bands also sight-read every live performance.

How to practice sight-reading

What is a good plan to pursue to improve the facility in sight-reading?

Practice looking ahead on your sheet music, and reading at least a few notes in advance.

Much reading and playing at sight and as fast as possible, even though at first some slight inaccuracies may creep in. By quick reading you develop that faculty of the eye which is meant by "grasp," and this, in turn, facilitates your reading of details.”

The best way to improve sight-reading

Is there any practical method that will assist one to greater rapidity in sight-reading?

“The best way to become a quick reader is first to be able to recognize hidden musical patterns; and second, to read as much as possible.

There are multiple levels in being able to recognize hidden musical patterns. The first level is being able to recognize chords and scales formed by the melody, which may appear in fragments. The second level is being able to recognize chord progressions, and different type of non-chord notes associated with their different harmonic functions (passing tones, anticipation, neighbor tone, escape tone, suspension, retardation, appoggiaturas, etc). The third level is being able to recognize the structure and form of the pieces.

The rapidity of your progress depends upon the state of your general musical education, for the more complete this is the better you will be able to surmise the logical sequel of a phrase once started. A large part of sight-reading consists of surmising, as you will find upon analyzing your book-reading.”

Hofmann’s answer was expanded with concepts from The Piano Encyclopedia’s Digital Home-Study Course: “The Logic Behind Music”. Just practicing reading sheet music again and again will not make your sight-reading skills grow. You need to practice intelligently and invest your time wisely. Hofmann was not just a pianist; he was also a composer and had a deep understanding of how music worked. Sight-reading is a skill that you will be able to develop once you have a deep understanding of music and are able to recognize its hidden patterns.

The problem of transposing at sight

What, please, is the quickest and safest way of transposing from one key to another? I have trouble, for instance, in playing for singing if the piece is in “A major” and the singer wants it in “F major”.

“The question of transposing hinges on the process of hearing through the eye. I mean by this that you must study the piece until you learn to conceive the printed music as sounds and sound groups, not as key pictures. Then transfer the sound picture to another tonality in your mind, very much as if when moving from one floor to another with all your household goods you were to place them on the new floor as they were placed on the old.

Practice will, of course, facilitate this process very much. Transposition at sight is based on somewhat different principles. Here you have to get mentally settled in the new tonality, and then follow the course of intervals.

If you find transposition difficult you may derive consolation from the thought that it is difficult for everybody, and that transposing at sight is, of course, still more difficult than to transpose after studying the piece beforehand.”

8109.title: Memorizing your music (Part 1/2)
8109.subtitle: The easiest way to memorize
8109.content:
ABOUT JÓZEF HOFMANN

Józef Hofmann is considered "one of the best pianists of all times". He was the only private student of the world-acclaimed pianist and composer Anton Rubinstein, who was the composition teacher of the legendary composer Tchaikovsky. The Piano Encyclopedia’s highly-trained staff of expert musicians has made a tremendous and elaborated investigation, digging up lost historical sources and combining them with modern expert knowledge, to provide you with the ultimate answers to every piano question.

The easiest way to memorize

Will you please tell me which is the easiest way to memorize a piano piece?

“Begin by playing it a few times very carefully and slowly until you can play it with a fair degree of exactitude (you need not mind an occasional stopping). Then go over such places as appeared to you especially complex until you understand their construction. Now let the piece rest for a whole day and try to trace in your mind the train of thoughts in the piece. Should you come to a dead stop be satisfied with what you have achieved. Your mind will keep on working, subconsciously, as over a puzzle, always trying to find the continuation.

If you find that the memory is a blank take the music in hand, look at the particular place—but only at this—and, since you have now found the connection, continue the work of mental tracing. At the next stop repeat this procedure until you have reached the end, not in every detail, but in large outlines. Of course, this does not mean that you can now play it from memory. You have only arrived at the point of transition from the imagined to the real, and now begins a new kind of study: to transfer to the instrument what you have mentally absorbed. Try to do this piece by piece, and look into the printed sheets (which should not be on the music-rack but away from it) only when your memory absolutely refuses to go on.

The real work with the printed music should be reserved to the last, and you should regard it in the light of a proof-reading of your mental impressions. The whole process of absorbing a piece of music mentally resembles that of photographing. The development of the acoustic picture (the tone-picture) is like the bath. The tentative playing is like the process of "fixing" against sensitiveness to lights; and the final work with the printed music is the retouching.”

Playing from memory is indispensable

Is memorization absolutely essential to a good player?

“Playing from memory is indispensable to the freedom of rendition. You have to bear in your mind and memory the whole piece in order to attend properly to its details. Some renowned players who take the printed sheets before them on the stage play, nevertheless, from memory. They take the music with them only to heighten their feeling of security and to counteract a lack of confidence in their memory—a species of nervousness.”

To keep errors from creeping in

I can always memorize a piece before I can play it fast. Do you advise practising with notes when I already know it by heart?

“You should always practice reading the sheet music many times until you are sure you are playing the correct notes. The occasional playing of a memorized piece from the notes will keep errors from creeping in, provided you read the music correctly and carefully.”

11001.title: Mistake #8: Unlocking the Hidden Secrets of the Piano Keyboard
11001.subtitle: Master Class
11001.description:
Welcome to "The 8 Mistakes Piano Players Should Avoid" series. In this mind-blowing eighth installment, we are about to reveal the hidden secrets of the piano keyboard that will revolutionize the way you play. Prepare yourself for an exhilarating journey into uncharted territory as we uncover the mysteries that most pianists overlook.

Have you ever wondered why the piano keyboard has black and white keys? What if we told you that these keys hold the answers to a musical language that transcends traditional teachings? Prepare to have your mind blown as we unravel the enigmatic relationship between the black and white keys, unveiling their purpose and power.

In this groundbreaking video, we will answer the burning questions that have kept you intrigued. Are the black keys less important than the white ones? Do they serve a different purpose? Prepare to have your perceptions shattered as we reveal that both black and white keys are essential and equally vital to creating beautiful melodies.

But the intrigue doesn't stop there. Ever found yourself lost among the keys, unable to find your way? We'll unveil the secret codes and patterns hidden within the piano's design, allowing you to effortlessly navigate the keyboard with absolute precision. You'll be astounded as we uncover the incredible braille-like system of the black keys, guiding you to the notes you seek.

11002.title: Mistake #7: Unveiling the Secret Behind Piano Playing: Music Palettes, Not Memorization
11002.subtitle: Master Class
11002.description:
In this eye-opening second installment of "The 8 Mistakes Piano Players Should Avoid," we expose the misconceptions surrounding learning piano and reveal the secret behind the playing of great pianists.

Many new players mistakenly believe that advanced pianists memorize hundreds of note combinations to perform intricate melodies. However, we are here to shatter that belief and introduce you to a smarter approach.

Smart pianists don't rely on memorization; instead, they understand which music notes harmonize well together. Just as a painter selects specific color palettes to convey emotions in their art, a smart musician knows precisely which notes to combine to create any type of music they desire.

We illustrate this concept using the example of blues music, where a specific combination of notes, known as the blues color palette, produces the authentic blues sound.

Prepare to be amazed as we demonstrate that the complexity of piano playing can be simplified by understanding various music palettes. The blues color palette is just one example among many, showcasing the natural harmony that occurs when specific groups of keys are played together. Great pianists possess the knowledge of which groups of keys naturally sound exceptional together and when to incorporate each palette, all without the need to memorize anything.

Join us in this revelatory video as we unveil the secret behind piano playing that will transform your approach to learning. Discover the power of music palettes and unlock the ability to create breathtaking melodies without the burden of extensive memorization. Get ready to elevate your piano playing to a whole new level of artistry and expression.

11003.title: Mistake #6: Debunking the Myth of Differences Between Small Electronic Keyboards and Full-Size Keyboards or Pianos
11003.subtitle: Master Class
11003.description:
In this revealing third installment of "The 8 Mistakes Piano Players Should Avoid," we debunk the common misconception that a small electronic keyboard is fundamentally different to play than a full-size keyboard or a real piano.

Prepare to have your preconceptions shattered as we dive deeper into the structure of the piano and unveil the truth.

The piano keyboard is divided into groups of 12 keys known as "octaves," which share the same structural pattern. The size of the keyboard depends on how many octaves it encompasses. Through a captivating demonstration, we illustrate that regardless of the size, the notes remain the same, and what changes within each octave is the pitch.

This means that you can play the exact same thing on any part of the keyboard, and it will sound the same, albeit with different pitch. Understanding this fundamental concept reveals that there is little difference in playing a larger or smaller keyboard. Once you master one size, you can effortlessly transition to playing any other, including full-size pianos.

We go even further to demystify the grand piano, often perceived as more challenging due to its larger size and additional keys. However, upon closer examination, we discover that the extra keys are simply parts of incomplete octaves added to increase the instrument's pitch range. In fact, these additional keys make the grand piano one of the instruments with the widest pitch range in existence, offering pianists endless possibilities for creativity.

Join us in this eye-opening video as we debunk the myth of differences between small electronic keyboards and full-size keyboards or pianos. Gain a new perspective on the keyboard's structure and unleash your potential to play across various keyboard sizes with ease. Prepare to embrace the versatility and expand your musical horizons like never before.

11004.title: Mistake #5: Breaking Free from the Typewriter Learning Method
11004.subtitle: Master Class
11004.description:
In this enlightening fourth installment of "The 8 Mistakes Piano Players Should Avoid," we delve into the pitfalls of following the typewriter learning method and highlight what to look for when searching for a piano teacher.

One of the key factors to consider is understanding the typewriter method, which is commonly found in conventional piano classes. In this approach, teachers primarily focus on teaching you how to read sheet music, neglecting to provide a comprehensive understanding of the instrument.

While learning songs may seem like the path to piano mastery, it's only part of the truth. Many teachers make you learn song after song without explaining the underlying logic behind the keys you're pressing. As a result, each new song becomes just as challenging to learn as the previous one, leaving you feeling stagnant in your progress.

Imagine yourself after a few years of such lessons. You may be able to flawlessly play Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata with sheet music, but without it, you would struggle to play even Happy Birthday at a party. Furthermore, if friends asked you to jam and improvise, you would likely have to decline if you solely rely on sheet music.

However, by embracing a method that focuses on the logic behind music, you not only read sheet music faster and learn songs more efficiently, but you also gain the ability to change them, improvise, and create your own music.

Join us in this eye-opening video as we break free from the typewriter learning method. Discover the importance of finding a teacher who emphasizes the understanding of musical logic and unlocks your true potential as a pianist. Say goodbye to the limitations of rote memorization and embark on a journey of musical expression and creativity.

11005.title: Mistake #4: Unlocking the Potential of Improvisation, Composition, and Playing by Ear
11005.subtitle: Master Class
11005.description:
In this eye-opening fifth installment of "The 8 Mistakes Piano Players Should Avoid," we debunk the notion that improvisation, composition, and playing by ear are exclusive talents reserved for the 'gifted.' Prepare to be amazed as we reveal that these skills are not inherent gifts but rather learnable abilities that can be honed and mastered, regardless of age or previous music experience.

Contrary to popular belief, improvisation, composition, and playing by ear can be learned relatively quickly when approached with the right mindset and tools. In this video, we highlight the importance of three fundamental aspects that unlock your potential in these areas. First, we explore the power of recognizing hidden musical patterns and leveraging them to your advantage. Next, we emphasize the significance of understanding how music works in a practical sense, providing a solid foundation for your creative endeavors. Lastly, we delve into the crucial role of applying the right tools at the right time to enhance your improvisation, composition, and ear-playing skills.

If you're eager to learn more about these three fundamental aspects and their interconnectedness, then pay close attention to the next three final mistakes in this series. Prepare to embark on a transformative journey that will empower you to tap into your musical potential and unleash the artist within. Say goodbye to the notion of being 'un-gifted' and embrace the limitless possibilities of improvisation, composition, and playing by ear.

11006.title: Mistake #3: Unveiling the Hidden Musical Patterns and Logic Behind Music
11006.subtitle: Master Class
11006.description:
In this captivating sixth installment of "The 8 Mistakes Piano Players Should Avoid," we unveil the truth about the existence of hidden musical patterns and the underlying logic behind music. Prepare to embark on a fascinating journey that will revolutionize your approach to piano playing and expand your creative possibilities.

Contrary to the common belief that music is devoid of patterns or logical structure, we reveal that understanding these patterns is the key to unlocking your musical potential. By delving into the fundamental aspects of music theory, you'll gain a deeper appreciation for the interconnectedness of notes and chords, enabling you to navigate the keyboard with confidence and fluidity.

Imagine being able to effortlessly transition between different styles and genres of music, from classical to jazz, pop to blues, and beyond. With a firm grasp of the hidden patterns and the logic of music, you'll have the tools to adapt and create your own unique interpretations of melodies and harmonies.

Rather than relying solely on sheet music or rote memorization, you'll develop the ability to play by ear, improvise, and compose your own music. Embrace the freedom and spontaneity that comes with understanding the hidden musical patterns, and unlock a world of endless creativity at your fingertips.

Join us as we explore the power of recognizing and utilizing these patterns, step-by-step, and discover how they can empower you to become the pianist you've always dreamed of being. Get ready to unlock the secrets of music and embark on a transformative musical journey that will forever change your relationship with the piano.

11007.title: Mistake #2: Unveiling the Transformative Tools in Music Learning
11007.subtitle: Master Class
11007.description:
In this eye-opening seventh installment of "The 8 Mistakes Piano Players Should Avoid," we debunk the misconception that there are no tools that make learning music easier. Prepare to be amazed as we reveal the transformative power of understanding the unique functions of every note on the piano and how they can be used as tools to completely transform your music.

Smart pianists know that by knowing which note does what, they can harness these notes as powerful tools to shape the emotion and expression of their melodies. Imagine being able to change the entire emotion of a melody by simply changing a specific single note. It may sound unbelievable, but we have a demonstration that will astound you.

We begin by improvising a melody using a set of colored keys on the screen, creating a happy and delightful sound. Then, we make a subtle change by replacing just one single note, and the entire feeling of the melody transforms from happiness to sadness and melancholy. With another change, we can bring back the cheerful tone once more. All this achieved by altering just one single note.

This example highlights the power of the tools available to you once you discover the logic behind music. It's just the beginning of what you can do when you have a deeper understanding of how music works in a practical way. Imagine the possibilities that unfold when you have a wide array of tools at your disposal to shape and express your musical ideas.

Join us in this enlightening video as we explore the transformative tools in music learning. Discover how understanding the unique functions of each note on the piano opens up a world of creative possibilities. Prepare to unlock the power of these tools and unleash your musical potential like never before. Get ready to embark on a musical journey that will empower you to shape and transform your music with precision and artistry.

11008.title: Mistake #1: Underestimating the Importance of Understanding How Music Works
11008.subtitle: Master Class
11008.description:
In this final and pivotal installment of "The 8 Mistakes Piano Players Should Avoid," we uncover the most important mistake: underestimating the importance of understanding how music works. Prepare to have your perspective transformed as we reveal the profound impact of grasping music's underlying logic.

By understanding music's logic, you gain a remarkable advantage over other piano players. We introduce the concept of "music formulas," which allow you to learn multiple songs in a single afternoon. We've proven this by making fifty of the greatest #1 hit songs playable with the same piano accompaniment. The secret lies in recognizing the shared music formula among these songs, unlocking the ability to play them effortlessly.

But music formulas are just the beginning. By delving deeper into music's logic, you gain the power to create your own music and play any song with ease. This knowledge frees you from the limitations of learning songs one by one and empowers you to express yourself in ways you never thought possible.

Join us in this final video as we emphasize the tremendous impact of understanding music's logic. Unlock the doors to limitless musical possibilities and embark on a lifelong journey of musical exploration. Don't underestimate the power that lies within your grasp. It's time to embrace the magic of music and unleash your full potential at the piano.

1100001.title: Fur Elise
1100001.subtitle: Beethoven, Ludwig Van
1100001.description: Beethoven’s Bagatelle in a (Fuer Elise) was composed on April 27, 1810 as a leaf in an album. Ludwig Nohl, who discovered the manuscript and published it in 1867, appears to have misread Beethoven’s writing of the name "Therese" (von Brunswick). She was the woman Beethoven reputedly loved and it was in her papers that the manuscript of Fuer Elise was discovered. It is one of the very best known and loved short works for piano.

1100137.title: How to Play 'Moonlight Sonata in C sharp minor, Op. 27, No.1, Adagio sostenuto'
1100137.subtitle: Beethoven, Ludwig Van
1100137.description: In 1802, Beethoven's Sonatina Quasi una Fantasia was published under the subtitle Moonlight. Beethoven's publishers were prompted to dub the sonata "Moonlight" by Heinrich Rellstab, who wrote that the first movement inspired the vision "of a boat on Lake Lucerne by a luminous night." The Moonlight Sonata in C sharp minor, Op. 27, was dedicated to one of Beethoven's many loves: the Countess Giulietta Guicciardi. Upon hearing the Moonlight Sonata, the listener is repeatedly reminded of Beethoven's remarkable emotive humanity. By beginning the Moonlight Sonata with a movement played Adagio sostenuto, Beethoven broke with traditional sonata form. Expessively lyric, this first movement is written in slow, melodic, eighth-note triplets, giving the piece a tranquil sadness.
